claims: A meeting should stop when its primary purpose is met (a decision is made, alignment is achieved, or necessary information is exchanged).
If the meeting has no clear purpose/desired outcome after an initial clarification window, continuing tends to create negative ROI; it should stop and be re-scoped.
Timeboxing is a default control: stop at the timebox unless there is an explicit, high-value reason to extend.
decisions: Adopt a primary stopping rule: stop when purpose is met OR when the timebox ends—whichever comes first.
Normalize ending early when outcomes are achieved (treat it as success, not rudeness).
open_questions: What observable signals show the purpose is met?
How do we stop a meeting cleanly without social discomfort or perceived disrespect?
next_actions: Enumerate concrete completion signals for common meeting types.
Draft a short facilitator script for ending early and for stopping when the purpose is unclear.

citations.note: General facilitation practice: timeboxes with explicit stop conditions; no external sources used.

rounds.summary: Baseline stop conditions: end when outcomes are achieved; stop and re-scope if purpose is unclear; respect timeboxes by default.

claims: A meeting should stop (or pause) when prerequisites are missing (needed decision-maker, required data, or shared context), because forward progress is impossible.
Stop when discussion is looping: participants are repeating the same arguments without adding new information, options, or convergence.
Stop when the marginal value of continued discussion is below the marginal cost of attendee time (negative marginal ROI).
If interaction becomes psychologically unsafe (escalation, personal attacks, or people shutting down), stopping or pausing preserves trust better than pushing through.
decisions: Add explicit stop triggers: missing prerequisites, looping, negative marginal ROI, and psychological-safety escalation.
Treat escalation as a hard pause/stop signal; reset with structure or a smaller group.
open_questions: What simple in-meeting heuristics approximate marginal ROI without heavy calculation?
What indicators best separate productive debate from harmful escalation?
next_actions: Create a short prerequisites checklist to run in the first 2–3 minutes.
Define a looping detector (e.g., 'same point repeated twice with no new info' or 'no new options in 10 minutes').
Define an escalation pause protocol (e.g., call a 2-minute break, restate shared goal, decide whether to continue).

citations.note: Economic marginal value framing applied to synchronous time; local reasoning only.
Facilitation norm: protect psychological safety; stop/pause when conversation becomes harmful; local general knowledge.

rounds.summary: Operational stop triggers: if you can’t progress (missing inputs), if you’re looping, if ROI goes negative, or if safety breaks down.

claims: Stop early when the remaining work is best done asynchronously (writing, compiling, drafting), then assign an owner and artifact.
Stop when the conversation decomposes into distinct subtopics needing different stakeholders; split the workstream instead of keeping everyone.
Stop when you have reached a decision-quality threshold; additional discussion increases confusion (analysis paralysis) more than it improves correctness.
A good stopping moment is when next steps are clear; continuing to 'polish' verbally often adds little compared to documenting and executing.
decisions: Introduce an 'async handoff' stopping rule for drafting/compiling work.
Use 'split-and-delegate' when the meeting becomes multiple meetings; end the plenary and schedule targeted follow-ups.
open_questions: What decision-quality threshold criteria fit different meeting types (status vs. decision vs. brainstorm)?
How do we ensure async handoffs reliably complete (prevent 'it fell through')?
next_actions: Define meeting-type stop criteria (decision, status, planning, brainstorming).
Create a handoff template: purpose, current state, decision needed, owner, deadline, and where it will be posted.
Add a rule: no meeting ends without captured decisions/actions/open issues.

citations.note: Local synthesis: reserve synchronous time for interaction and decisions; move drafting to async when possible.

rounds.summary: Round 3 focuses on format choice: end meetings when async work, splitting threads, or decision-quality thresholds make continued plenary time wasteful.

claims: Stop when the meeting has drifted from the original goal (scope drift); re-charter the objective or schedule a new session with the correct scope and attendees.
Stop when the group is effectively converged but continues for reassurance or habit; provide a crisp recap and close.
For recurring meetings, stop/cancel/redesign if repeated cycles do not produce outputs (decisions, actions, resolved issues).
Adding explicit 'completion checks' (e.g., a midpoint and final 'are we done?' checkpoint) legitimizes ending early and surfaces hidden blockers.
decisions: Add scope drift and reassurance loops as explicit stopping conditions.
Adopt a recurring-meeting health rule: if output is consistently low over several instances, redesign or cancel.
Standardize completion checkpoints to normalize ending early.
open_questions: What is a reasonable threshold (N meetings) for 'consistently low output' before canceling/redesigning?
How can leaders reduce the social pressure to 'use the whole hour'?
next_actions: Propose a lightweight metric: outputs per hour (decisions + actions + resolved blockers).
Draft scripts: (1) scope drift reset, (2) reassurance-loop close.
Set a default threshold (e.g., N=3) with an explicit override policy.

citations.note: Local practice: periodically evaluate recurring rituals with simple output metrics; no external sources used.

rounds.summary: Round 4 adds meta-level stopping: end scope drift, end reassurance loops, and cancel/redesign recurring meetings that repeatedly fail to create outputs; use explicit completion checks.

claims: Most stopping triggers can be summarized into three buckets: (1) achieved (outcome reached), (2) blocked (can’t progress), (3) suboptimal (better done elsewhere/async or ROI is negative).
Stopping feels easier when framed as respect for time: 'We’ve got what we need; let’s give time back.'
A consistent closing ritual reduces anxiety about ending early by ensuring alignment is captured before people leave.
decisions: Consolidate prior rounds into a 3-bucket stopping taxonomy.
Adopt a standard closing ritual: recap decisions, recap actions (owner+date), list open issues, confirm communication channel, then end.
open_questions: What closing ritual is shortest while still preventing post-meeting confusion?
next_actions: Write a one-page 'When to stop a meeting' guide using the 3-bucket taxonomy.
Create a meeting-notes footer template that matches the closing ritual.

citations.note: Synthesis of rounds 1–4; novelty intentionally reduced.

rounds.summary: Round 5 mostly synthesizes: a compact 3-bucket model plus a predictable closing ritual; limited new concepts by design.

claims: When uncertain whether to stop, use a fast 'continue?' check: end now, extend briefly with a specific objective, or schedule a follow-up with a smaller group.
Extensions should be small and objective-bound; otherwise end and convert the remainder into an assigned artifact or follow-up.
The main risk of stopping early is loss of alignment; mitigate by documenting decisions, actions, and open issues before closing.
decisions: Add a minimal ambiguity protocol: quick check + tiny extensions only with explicit objective.
Re-emphasize documentation as the safety net when stopping early.
open_questions: How should the 'continue?' check be run in very large meetings without itself becoming a time sink?
next_actions: Provide two variants of the check: verbal (small meetings) and chat/poll (large meetings).
Add a final checklist item to the closing ritual: 'Have we captured decisions/actions/open issues in a shared place?'

citations.note: Common facilitation pattern: quick temperature checks (e.g., brief polling) to decide whether to continue; local general knowledge.

rounds.summary: Round 6 adds only small refinements (a quick 'continue?' protocol) and reiterates documentation; novelty is intentionally low to reflect diminishing returns.

novelty_profile.rounds_3_to_4: Structural improvements (async handoff, split meetings, scope drift, recurring-meeting evaluation).
novelty_profile.rounds_5_to_6: Synthesis and light protocol refinements; minimal new conceptual structure.

diminishing_returns_note.rationale: By round 5, the model is stable; additional rounds mostly package the same ideas into scripts/templates and add minor facilitation mechanics.
